Localisation.report_string:
--- Localisation ---
Agree with lesions involving:
- left optic nerve, left midbrain and right medulla.

Differential diagnosis.report_string:
--- Differential diagnosis ---
Correctly included Multiple sclerosis.

Agree to also consider:
- NMOSD (AQP4+), MOGAD, Neurosarcoid, SLE, Vasculitis, Sjogren's and Behçet's.

Other possible differentials:
- Neurosyphilis.
- Also feasible but of low probability: Leptomeningeal carcinomatosis, ADEM, Lymphoma and Lyme.

The following suggested diagnoses have a low probability of providing a unifying explanation for the full clinical presentation:
- Brainstem or cervicomedullary tumour (e.g. glioma, meningioma) with coexisting optic neuropathy (plausible for bilateral brainstem; but atypical for unilateral optic nerve involvement)
- Vitamin B12 deficiency with subacute combined degeneration of the cord (atypical for bilateral brainstem and strictly unilateral optic nerve involvement)

ft_diagnoses_raw: Neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder (aquaporin-4 IgG associated)
Primary CNS vasculitis or systemic autoimmune disease with CNS involvement (e.g. systemic lupus erythematosus, Sjögren syndrome, Behçet disease)
Brainstem or cervicomedullary tumour (e.g. glioma, meningioma) with coexisting optic neuropathy
Vitamin B12 deficiency with subacute combined degeneration of the cord
additional_diagnoses: Brainstem or cervicomedullary tumour (e.g. glioma, meningioma) with coexisting optic neuropathy
Vitamin B12 deficiency with subacute combined degeneration of the cord

Investigations.report_string:
--- Investigations ---

- Agree with the suggested MRI including the Brain and Orbits and CSF test for Oligoclonal Bands - would potentially inform a diagnosis/details of multiple sclerosis.

To evaluate other differential diagnoses:
- Agree with considering: anti-dsDNA, anti-MOG, ANA, CRP, ENA, ACE, ANCA, HIV, anti-AQP4, syphilis, ESR, lyme.
- Could also consider testing: CSF (flow cytometry and cytology).

ft_proposed_investigations: MRI of brain, orbits and whole spine with gadolinium
Lumbar puncture for CSF opening pressure, cell count, protein and glucose
CSF oligoclonal bands and IgG index
CSF microbiology and viral PCR panel as indicated
Optical coherence tomography of retinal nerve fibre layer
Syphilis serology (TPHA and RPR or equivalent)
Quantiferon-TB Gold test or tuberculin skin test
Pregnancy test (beta-hCG) in women of childbearing potential
Chest CT scan with contrast (to assess for sarcoidosis or malignancy when suspected)

Management.report_string:
--- Management ---
Steroids: Not appropriate to start treatment immediately.
  
Additional factors not mentioned:

- Evidence of potential active intercurrent infection (Urine: Leucocytes ++, Blood +).

- Presenting complaint is not specified, so no indication what the current issue is and whether neurological signs are new or old.

- Timing of current symptoms not specified, so no indication whether this is a recent issue or old deficit.

DMTs: Appropriate to consider but delay treatment.
  
Correctly identified the following:

- Need confirmation of MS diagnosis.

- Need for a pregnancy test result is not mentioned in this answer, but was included in Investigations, so we will give benefit of the doubt.
  
Additional factors not mentioned:

- Evidence of potential active intercurrent infection (Urine: Leucocytes ++, Blood +).

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: High-dose intravenous methylprednisolone 1 g daily for 3–5 days
reasons: Standard first-line therapy for an acute, functionally significant CNS demyelinating relapse
Aims to reduce inflammation and shorten the duration and severity of neurological deficits
Risk–benefit profile is favourable in a young patient once active infection and contraindications are excluded

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Proton pump inhibitor during and shortly after high-dose steroid therapy
reasons: Reduces risk of steroid-induced gastric irritation or peptic ulceration
Patient will receive several days of high-dose corticosteroids

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Thromboprophylaxis with low-molecular-weight heparin and graduated compression stockings
reasons: Spastic tetraparesis and reduced mobility increase venous thromboembolism risk
High-dose steroids may further increase thrombotic risk

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Targeted antibiotic therapy for urinary tract infection
reasons: Urinalysis shows leucocytes and blood suggesting urinary tract infection
Active infection should be treated before or alongside high-dose immunosuppression to reduce sepsis risk

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Neurology-led multidisciplinary rehabilitation (physiotherapy, occupational therapy, and speech and language therapy)
reasons: Spastic tetraparesis, gait ataxia and bulbar signs require early rehabilitation to prevent contractures and aspiration and to maximise functional recovery
Supports gait training, balance, activities of daily living and swallowing/communication assessment

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Oral antispasticity agents such as baclofen or tizanidine
reasons: Assess response to steroids and physiotherapy first, as spasticity may improve with remission
Initiate if clinically significant spasticity persists and impairs function or causes pain

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Disease-modifying therapy for multiple sclerosis (e.g. ocrelizumab, natalizumab or other agent according to risk stratification)
reasons: Requires firm diagnosis of multiple sclerosis with MRI and CSF evidence of dissemination in time and space
Needs baseline infection screening, vaccination review and detailed discussion of risks and benefits with the patient
Choice of agent should be individualised in a specialist MS clinic
Reserved for severe demyelinating relapses not responding adequately to high-dose steroids
Invasive treatment with significant risks, so only indicated if there is persistent, disabling deficit after initial therapy

ft_plan.treatment: High-dose intravenous methylprednisolone 1 g daily for 3–5 days
reasons: Standard first-line therapy for an acute, functionally significant CNS demyelinating relapse
Aims to reduce inflammation and shorten the duration and severity of neurological deficits
Risk–benefit profile is favourable in a young patient once active infection and contraindications are excluded

missing_information: Presenting complaint is not specified, so no indication whether this is related to MS.
Timing of current symptoms not specified, so no indication whether this is a recent issue or old deficit.
contraindications: Evidence of potential active intercurrent infection (Urine: Leucocytes ++, Blood +).
